answers.answer: Your symptoms do not suggest optic neuritis nor multiple sclerosis. They are consistent with entopic phenomena such as phosphenes.  Unless something changes I think you need not worry about them.JCH III MD

Clarification:I am not sure if what I am seeing are "phosphese" or "flashers" or what the difference is between the two, if any.  I see a tiny, bright "spark" in my peripheral vision, often at the outside edge or the top - I cannot tell which eye it is - and it happens quite often.  They go away almost instantly. No eye pain that I've noticed.  The opthamologist who examined me last month did so with my pupils dilated.  At the time I had had several episodes of visual auras - scintillating blobs in one eye that got larger until it disappeared from my view, lasting approx. 15 minutes.  She diagnosed me with opthalmic migraines.  I had three last Nov/Dec - I have not had any since - just the flashers.thanks

question: Hi there:About one year ago, I started noticing what I believe are called "phosphenes" - little "sparks" of light in my field of vision that come and go briefly. I was pregnant at the time I noticed them and was concerned about preeclampsia. Once that was ruled I out I pretty much ignored them. I'm not sure if I've had them for the entire year or if I've just noticed them again recently, but I am noticing them often now for the past two months.Questions:1. I understand phosphenes can be a sign of MS, which worries me.  Is there any other eye-related explanation which could account for these (assuming they are related, which they may not be)?   I saw an opthamologist in early January about opthalmic migraines and she said my eyes were OK.2. If this were optic neuritis, would it have been picked up by the opthamologist?3. If it were ON, would it have progressed more by now? (I started seeing the phosphenes last year).
title: vertigo/phosphenes
